sn56.42:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
sn56.42:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

sn56.42:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

sn56.42:1.3.eng: “Come, mendicants, let’s go to Inspiration Peak for the day’s meditation.”

sn56.42:1.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn56.42:1.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ yena paṭibhānakūṭo tenupasaṅkami.
sn56.42:1.5.eng: Then the Buddha together with several mendicants went to Inspiration Peak.

sn56.42:1.6.pli: Addasā kho aññataro bhikkhu paṭibhānakūṭe mahantaṃ papātaṃ.
sn56.42:1.6.eng: A certain mendicant saw the big cliff there

sn56.42:1.8.pli: “mahā vatāyaṃ, bhante, papāto subhayānako, bhante, papāto.
sn56.42:1.8.eng: “Sir, that big cliff is really huge and scary.

sn56.42:1.9.pli: Atthi nu kho, bhante, imamhā papātā añño papāto mahantataro ca bhayānakataro cā”ti?
sn56.42:1.9.eng: Is there any other cliff bigger and scarier than this one?”

sn56.42:1.10.pli: “Atthi kho, bhikkhu, imamhā papātā añño papāto mahantataro ca bhayānakataro cā”ti.

sn56.42:2.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, imamhā papātā añño papāto mahantataro ca bhayānakataro cā”ti?

sn56.42:2.2.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti,
sn56.42:2.2.eng: “Mendicant, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.42:2.3.pli: te jātisaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu abhiramanti, jarāsaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu abhiramanti, maraṇasaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu abhiramanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsasaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu abhiramanti.
sn56.42:2.3.eng: They take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.42:2.4.pli: Te jātisaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu abhiratā jarāsaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu abhiratā maraṇasaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu abhiratā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsasaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu abhiratā jātisaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharonti, jarāsaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharonti, maraṇasaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharonti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsasaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharonti.
sn56.42:2.4.eng: Since they take pleasure in such choices, they continue to make them.

sn56.42:2.5.pli: Te jātisaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharitvā jarāsaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharitvā maraṇasaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharitvā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsasaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharitvā jātipapātampi papatanti, jarāpapātampi papatanti, maraṇapapātampi papatanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsapapātampi papatanti.
sn56.42:2.5.eng: Having made choices that lead to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, they fall down the cliff of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.42:2.6.pli: Te na parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
sn56.42:2.6.eng: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.42:2.7.eng: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.

sn56.42:3.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti …pe…
sn56.42:3.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.42:3.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, te jātisaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu nābhiramanti, jarāsaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu nābhiramanti, maraṇasaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu nābhiramanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsasaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu nābhiramanti.
sn56.42:3.2.eng: They don’t take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.42:3.3.pli: Te jātisaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu anabhiratā, jarāsaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu anabhiratā, maraṇasaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu anabhiratā, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsasaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu anabhiratā, jātisaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre nābhisaṅkharonti, jarāsaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre nābhisaṅkharonti, maraṇasaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre nābhisaṅkharonti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsasaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre nābhisaṅkharonti.
sn56.42:3.3.eng: Since they don’t take pleasure in such choices, they stop making them.

sn56.42:3.4.pli: Te jātisaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre anabhisaṅkharitvā, jarāsaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre anabhisaṅkharitvā, maraṇasaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre anabhisaṅkharitvā, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsasaṃvattanikepi saṅkhāre anabhisaṅkharitvā, jātipapātampi nappapatanti, jarāpapātampi nappapatanti, maraṇapapātampi nappapatanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsapapātampi nappapatanti.
sn56.42:3.4.eng: Having stopped making choices that lead to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, they don’t fall down the cliff of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.42:3.5.pli: Te parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
sn56.42:3.5.eng: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.42:3.6.eng: They’re freed from suffering, I say.

sn56.42:4.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.42:4.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.43:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there is a hell called ‘The Mighty Fever’.

sn56.43:1.2.pli: Tattha yaṃ kiñci cakkhunā rūpaṃ passati, aniṭṭharūpaññeva passati no iṭṭharūpaṃ; akantarūpaññeva passati no kantarūpaṃ; amanāparūpaññeva passati no manāparūpaṃ.
sn56.43:1.2.eng: There, whatever sight you see with your eye is unlikable, not likable; undesirable, not desirable; unpleasant, not pleasant.

sn56.43:1.3.eng: Whatever sound you hear … Whatever odor you smell … Whatever flavor you taste …

sn56.43:1.5.pli: yaṃ kiñci manasā dhammaṃ vijānāti, aniṭṭharūpaññeva vijānāti no iṭṭharūpaṃ; akantarūpaññeva vijānāti no kantarūpaṃ; amanāparūpaññeva vijānāti no manāparūpan”ti.
sn56.43:1.5.eng: Whatever idea you know with your mind is unlikable, not likable; undesirable, not desirable; unpleasant, not pleasant.”

sn56.43:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn56.43:2.1.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,

sn56.43:2.2.pli: “mahā vata so, bhante, pariḷāho, sumahā vata so, bhante, pariḷāho.
sn56.43:2.2.eng: “Sir, that fever really is mighty, so very mighty.

sn56.43:2.3.pli: Atthi nu kho, bhante, etamhā pariḷāhā añño pariḷāho mahantataro ceva bhayānakataro cā”ti?
sn56.43:2.3.eng: Is there any other fever more mighty and terrifying than this one?”

sn56.43:2.4.pli: “Atthi kho, bhikkhu, etamhā pariḷāhā añño pariḷāho mahantataro ca bhayānakataro cā”ti.

sn56.43:3.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, etamhā pariḷāhā añño pariḷāho mahantataro ca bhayānakataro cā”ti?

sn56.43:3.2.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn56.43:3.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.43:3.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, te jātisaṃvattanikesu saṅkhāresu abhiramanti …pe…
sn56.43:3.3.eng: They take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …

sn56.43:3.4.eng: They continue to make such choices …

sn56.43:3.5.pli: abhisaṅkharitvā jātipariḷāhenapi pariḍayhanti, jarāpariḷāhenapi pariḍayhanti, maraṇapariḷāhenapi pariḍayhanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsapariḷāhenapi pariḍayhanti.
sn56.43:3.5.eng: Having made such choices, they burn with the fever of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.43:3.6.pli: Te na parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
sn56.43:3.6.eng: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.43:3.7.eng: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.

sn56.43:4.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti.
sn56.43:4.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.43:4.2.eng: They don’t take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …

sn56.43:4.4.pli: anabhisaṅkharitvā jātipariḷāhenapi na pariḍayhanti, jarāpariḷāhenapi na pariḍayhanti, maraṇapariḷāhenapi na pariḍayhanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsapariḷāhenapi na pariḍayhanti.
sn56.43:4.4.eng: Having stopped making such choices, they don’t burn with the fever of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.43:4.5.pli: Te parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
sn56.43:4.5.eng: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.43:4.6.eng: They’re freed from suffering, I say.

sn56.43:5.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.43:5.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.44:1.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ anabhisamecca …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ anabhisamecca sammā dukkhassantaṃ karissāmī’ti—
sn56.44:1.2.eng: ‘Without truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, I will completely make an end of suffering.’

sn56.44:2.1.eng: It’s as if someone were to say:

sn56.44:2.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ kūṭāgārassa heṭṭhimaṃ gharaṃ akaritvā uparimaṃ gharaṃ āropessāmī’ti—
sn56.44:2.2.eng: ‘Before the lower story of a bungalow is built, I will hoist up the upper story.’

sn56.44:2.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yo evaṃ vadeyya:
sn56.44:2.4.eng: In the same way, suppose someone were to say:

sn56.44:2.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ anabhisamecca …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ anabhisamecca sammā dukkhassantaṃ karissāmī’ti—
sn56.44:2.5.eng: ‘Without truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, I will completely make an end of suffering.’

sn56.44:3.1.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, evaṃ vadeyya:
sn56.44:3.1.eng: But suppose someone were to say:

sn56.44:3.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamecca …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamecca sammā dukkhassantaṃ karissāmī’ti—
sn56.44:3.2.eng: ‘After truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, I will completely make an end of suffering.’

sn56.44:4.1.eng: It’s as if someone were to say:

sn56.44:4.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ kūṭāgārassa heṭṭhimaṃ gharaṃ karitvā uparimaṃ gharaṃ āropessāmī’ti—
sn56.44:4.2.eng: ‘After the lower story of a bungalow is built, I will hoist up the upper story.’

sn56.44:4.4.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yo evaṃ vadeyya:
sn56.44:4.4.eng: In the same way, suppose someone were to say:

sn56.44:4.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamecca …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ ariyasaccaṃ yathābhūtaṃ abhisamecca sammā dukkhassantaṃ karissāmī’ti—
sn56.44:4.5.eng: ‘After truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, I will completely make an end of suffering.’

sn56.44:5.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.44:5.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.45:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn56.45:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

sn56.45:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn56.45:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.

sn56.45:1.3.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā ānando sambahule licchavikumārake santhāgāre upāsanaṃ karonte, dūratova sukhumena tāḷacchiggaḷena asanaṃ atipātente, poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ avirādhitaṃ.
sn56.45:1.3.eng: He saw several Licchavi youths practicing archery near the town hall. They were shooting arrows from a distance through a small keyhole, shot after shot without missing.

sn56.45:1.4.eng: When he saw this he thought,

sn56.45:1.5.eng: “These Licchavi youths really are trained, so well trained,

sn56.45:1.6.pli: yatra hi nāma dūratova sukhumena tāḷacchiggaḷena asanaṃ atipātessanti poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ avirādhitan”ti.
sn56.45:1.6.eng: in that they shoot arrows from a distance through a small keyhole, shot after shot without missing.”

sn56.45:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando vesāliṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn56.45:2.1.eng: Then Ānanda wandered for alms in Vesālī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

sn56.45:2.2.pli: “idhāhaṃ, bhante, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ.

sn56.45:2.3.pli: Addasaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, sambahule licchavikumārake santhāgāre upāsanaṃ karonte dūratova sukhumena tāḷacchiggaḷena asanaṃ atipātente poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ avirādhitaṃ.

sn56.45:2.6.pli: yatra hi nāma dūratova sukhumena tāḷacchiggaḷena asanaṃ atipātessanti poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ avirādhitan’”ti.

sn56.45:3.2.pli: katamaṃ nu kho dukkarataraṃ vā durabhisambhavataraṃ vā—
sn56.45:3.2.eng: Which is harder and more challenging:

sn56.45:3.3.pli: yo dūratova sukhumena tāḷacchiggaḷena asanaṃ atipāteyya poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ avirādhitaṃ, yo vā sattadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭivijjheyyā”ti?
sn56.45:3.3.eng: to shoot arrows from a distance through a small keyhole, shot after shot without missing? Or to take a horsehair split into seven strands and penetrate one tip with another tip?”

sn56.45:3.4.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, dukkaratarañceva durabhisambhavatarañca yo vā sattadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭivijjheyyā”ti.
sn56.45:3.4.eng: “It’s more difficult and challenging, sir, to take a horsehair split into seven strands and penetrate one tip with another tip.”

sn56.45:3.5.pli: “Atha kho, ānanda, duppaṭivijjhataraṃ paṭivijjhanti, ye ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ paṭivijjhanti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ paṭivijjhanti.
sn56.45:3.5.eng: “Still, Ānanda, those who truly penetrate suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path penetrate something tougher than that.

sn56.45:4.1.pli: Tasmātihānanda, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.45:4.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.46:1.1.pli: “Atthi, bhikkhave, lokantarikā aghā asaṃvutā andhakārā andhakāratimisā, yatthamimesaṃ candimasūriyānaṃ evaṃmahiddhikānaṃ evaṃ mahānubhāvānaṃ ābhāya nānubhontī”ti.
sn56.46:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the boundless gloom of interstellar space is so utterly dark that even the luminosity of the moon and the sun, so mighty and powerful, makes no impression.”

sn56.46:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn56.46:2.1.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,

sn56.46:2.2.pli: “mahā vata so, bhante, andhakāro, sumahā vata so, bhante, andhakāro.
sn56.46:2.2.eng: “Sir, that darkness really is mighty, so very mighty.

sn56.46:2.3.pli: Atthi nu kho, bhante, etamhā andhakārā añño andhakāro mahantataro ca bhayānakataro cā”ti?
sn56.46:2.3.eng: Is there any other darkness more mighty and terrifying than this one?”

sn56.46:2.4.pli: “Atthi kho, bhikkhu, etamhā andhakārā añño andhakāro mahantataro ca bhayānakataro cā”ti.

sn56.46:3.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, etamhā andhakārā añño andhakāro mahantataro ca bhayānakataro cā”ti?

sn56.46:3.2.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhu, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti,
sn56.46:3.2.eng: “There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.46:3.3.eng: They take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …

sn56.46:3.4.eng: They continue to make such choices …

sn56.46:3.5.pli: abhisaṅkharitvā jātandhakārampi papatanti, jarandhakārampi papatanti, maraṇandhakārampi papatanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsandhakārampi papatanti.
sn56.46:3.5.eng: Having made such choices, they fall into the darkness of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.46:3.6.pli: Te na parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
sn56.46:3.6.eng: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.46:3.7.eng: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.

sn56.46:4.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhu, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti,
sn56.46:4.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.46:4.2.eng: They don’t take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth …

sn56.46:4.4.pli: anabhisaṅkharitvā jātandhakārampi nappapatanti, jarandhakārampi nappapatanti, maraṇandhakārampi nappapatanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsandhakārampi nappapatanti.
sn56.46:4.4.eng: Having stopped making such choices, they don’t fall into the darkness of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.46:4.5.pli: Te parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
sn56.46:4.5.eng: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn56.46:4.6.eng: They’re freed from suffering, I say.

sn56.46:5.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.46:5.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.47:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso mahāsamudde ekacchiggaḷaṃ yugaṃ pakkhipeyya. Tatrāpissa kāṇo kacchapo. So vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena sakiṃ sakiṃ ummujjeyya.
sn56.47:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a person were to throw a yoke with a single hole into the ocean. And there was a one-eyed turtle who popped up once every hundred years.

sn56.47:1.3.pli: api nu kho kāṇo kacchapo vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena sakiṃ sakiṃ ummujjanto amusmiṃ ekacchiggaḷe yuge gīvaṃ paveseyyā”ti?
sn56.47:1.3.eng: Would that one-eyed turtle, popping up once every hundred years, still poke its neck through the hole in that yoke?”

sn56.47:1.4.pli: “Yadi nūna, bhante, kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayenā”ti.
sn56.47:1.4.eng: “Only after a very long time, sir, if ever.”

sn56.47:2.1.pli: “Khippataraṃ kho so, bhikkhave, kāṇo kacchapo vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena sakiṃ sakiṃ ummujjanto amusmiṃ ekacchiggaḷe yuge gīvaṃ paveseyya, na tvevāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sakiṃ vinipātagatena bālena manussattaṃ vadāmi.
sn56.47:2.1.eng: “That one-eyed turtle might poke its neck through the hole in that yoke, but in any case it’d be sooner than a fool fallen to the underworld is reborn as a human being, I say.

sn56.47:3.2.pli: Na hettha, bhikkhave, atthi dhammacariyā, samacariyā, kusalakiriyā, puññakiriyā.
sn56.47:3.2.eng: Because in that place there’s no principled or moral conduct, and no doing what is good and skillful.

sn56.47:3.3.eng: There they just prey on each other, preying on the weak.

sn56.47:3.5.eng: It’s because they haven’t seen the four noble truths.

sn56.47:3.7.eng: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.47:4.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.47:4.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.48:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose the earth was entirely covered with water.

sn56.48:1.2.eng: And a person threw a yoke with a single hole into it.

sn56.48:1.3.pli: Tamenaṃ puratthimo vāto pacchimena saṃhareyya, pacchimo vāto puratthimena saṃhareyya, uttaro vāto dakkhiṇena saṃhareyya, dakkhiṇo vāto uttarena saṃhareyya.
sn56.48:1.3.eng: The east wind wafts it west; the west wind wafts it east; the north wind wafts it south; and the south wind wafts it north.

sn56.48:1.4.pli: Tatrassa kāṇo kacchapo. So vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena sakiṃ sakiṃ ummujjeyya.
sn56.48:1.4.eng: And there was a one-eyed turtle who popped up once every hundred years.

sn56.48:1.6.pli: api nu kho kāṇo kacchapo vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena sakiṃ sakiṃ ummujjanto amusmiṃ ekacchiggaḷe yuge gīvaṃ paveseyyā”ti?
sn56.48:1.6.eng: Would that one-eyed turtle, popping up once every hundred years, still poke its neck through the hole in that yoke?”

sn56.48:1.7.pli: “Adhiccamidaṃ, bhante, yaṃ so kāṇo kacchapo vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena sakiṃ sakiṃ ummujjanto amusmiṃ ekacchiggaḷe yuge gīvaṃ paveseyyā”ti.

sn56.48:2.1.eng: “That’s how unlikely it is to get reborn as a human being.

sn56.48:2.2.pli: Evaṃ adhiccamidaṃ, bhikkhave, yaṃ tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho.
sn56.48:2.2.eng: And that’s how unlikely it is for a Realized One to arise in the world, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.

sn56.48:2.3.pli: Evaṃ adhiccamidaṃ, bhikkhave, yaṃ tathāgatappavedito dhammavinayo loke dibbati.
sn56.48:2.3.eng: And that’s how unlikely it is for the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One to shine in the world.

sn56.48:2.4.pli: Tassidaṃ, bhikkhave, manussattaṃ laddhaṃ, tathāgato loke uppanno arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, tathāgatappavedito ca dhammavinayo loke dibbati.
sn56.48:2.4.eng: And now, mendicants, you have been reborn as a human being. A Realized One has arisen in the world, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha. And the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One shines in the world.

sn56.48:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.48:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.49:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso sinerussa pabbatarājassa satta muggamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhipeyya.
sn56.49:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a person was to place on Sineru, the king of mountains, seven pebbles the size of mung beans.

sn56.49:1.3.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yā vā satta muggamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā, yo vā sinerupabbatarājā”ti?
sn56.49:1.3.eng: Which is more: the seven pebbles the size of mung beans? Or Sineru, the king of mountains?”

sn56.49:1.4.eng: “Sir, Sineru, the king of mountains, is certainly more.

sn56.49:1.5.eng: The seven pebbles the size of mung beans are tiny.

sn56.49:1.6.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti sinerupabbatarājānaṃ upanidhāya satta muggamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā”ti.
sn56.49:1.6.eng: Compared to Sineru, they don’t count, there’s no comparison, they’re not worth a fraction.”

sn56.49:1.7.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa diṭṭhisampannassa puggalassa abhisametāvino etadeva bahutaraṃ dukkhaṃ yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ; appamattakaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ.
sn56.49:1.7.eng: “In the same way, for an individual with comprehension, a noble disciple accomplished in view, the suffering that’s over and done with is more, what’s left is tiny.

sn56.49:1.8.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti, purimaṃ dukkhakkhandhaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ upanidhāya yadidaṃ sattakkhattuparamatā;
sn56.49:1.8.eng: Compared to the mass of suffering in the past that’s over and done with, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction, since there are at most seven more lives.

sn56.49:1.9.pli: yo ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn56.49:1.9.eng: Such an individual truly understands about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.49:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.49:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.5:1.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambojjhiṃsu, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambojjhiṃsu.
sn56.5:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, whatever ascetics and brahmins truly awaken—in the past,

sn56.5:1.2.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, anāgatamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambojjhissanti, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambojjhissanti.

sn56.5:1.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambojjhanti, sabbe te cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambojjhanti.
sn56.5:1.3.eng: or present—all of them truly awaken to the four noble truths.

sn56.5:2.2.eng: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. …

sn56.5:2.3.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā yathābhūtaṃ abhisambojjhiṃsu …pe…

sn56.5:2.5.pli: abhisambojjhanti, sabbe te imāni cattāri ariyasaccāni yathābhūtaṃ abhisambojjhanti.

sn56.5:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.5:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.50:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, sinerupabbatarājāyaṃ parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, ṭhapetvā satta muggamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā.
sn56.50:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose Sineru, the king of mountains, was worn away and eroded except for seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds.

sn56.50:1.3.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yaṃ vā sinerussa pabbatarājassa parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ, yā vā satta muggamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā avasiṭṭhā”ti?
sn56.50:1.3.eng: Which is more: the portion of Sineru, the king of mountains, that has been worn away and eroded? Or the seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds that are left?”

sn56.50:1.4.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ sinerussa pabbatarājassa yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ;
sn56.50:1.4.eng: “Sir, the portion of Sineru, the king of mountains, that has been worn away and eroded is certainly more.

sn56.50:1.5.eng: The seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds are tiny.

sn56.50:1.6.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti sinerussa pabbatarājassa parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ upanidhāya satta muggamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā avasiṭṭhā”ti.
sn56.50:1.6.eng: Compared to Sineru, they don’t count, there’s no comparison, they’re not worth a fraction.”

sn56.50:1.7.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa diṭṭhisampannassa puggalassa abhisametāvino etadeva bahutaraṃ dukkhaṃ yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ; appamattakaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ.
sn56.50:1.7.eng: “In the same way, for an individual with comprehension, a noble disciple accomplished in view, the suffering that’s over and done with is more, what’s left is tiny.

sn56.50:1.8.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti, purimaṃ dukkhakkhandhaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ upanidhāya yadidaṃ sattakkhattuparamatā;
sn56.50:1.8.eng: Compared to the mass of suffering in the past that’s over and done with, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction, since there are at most seven more lives.

sn56.50:1.9.pli: yo ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn56.50:1.9.eng: Such an individual truly understands about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.50:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.50:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.51:1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā parittaṃ nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsuṃ āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn56.51:1.1.eng: Then the Buddha, picking up a little bit of dirt on his fingernail, addressed the mendicants:

sn56.51:1.3.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yo vāyaṃ mayā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito, ayaṃ vā mahāpathavī”ti?
sn56.51:1.3.eng: Which is more: the little bit of dirt on my fingernail, or this great earth?”

sn56.51:1.4.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ yadidaṃ—mahāpathavī; appamattakāyaṃ bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito.
sn56.51:1.4.eng: “Sir, the great earth is certainly more. The little bit of dirt on your fingernail is tiny.

sn56.51:1.5.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti mahāpathaviṃ upanidhāya bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito”ti.
sn56.51:1.5.eng: Compared to the great earth, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”

sn56.51:1.6.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa diṭṭhisampannassa puggalassa abhisametāvino etadeva bahutaraṃ dukkhaṃ yadidaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ; appamattakaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ.
sn56.51:1.6.eng: “In the same way, for an individual with comprehension, a noble disciple accomplished in view, the suffering that’s over and done with is more, what’s left is tiny.

sn56.51:1.7.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti purimaṃ dukkhakkhandhaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ pariyādinnaṃ upanidhāya yadidaṃ sattakkhattuparamatā;
sn56.51:1.7.eng: Compared to the mass of suffering in the past that’s over and done with, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction, since there are at most seven more lives.

sn56.51:1.8.pli: yo ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn56.51:1.8.eng: Such an individual truly understands about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

sn56.51:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.51:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.52:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, pokkharaṇī paññāsayojanāni āyāmena, paññāsayojanāni vitthārena, paññāsayojanāni ubbedhena, puṇṇā udakassa samatittikā kākapeyyā.
sn56.52:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose there was a lotus pond that was fifty leagues long, fifty leagues wide, and fifty leagues deep, full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.

sn56.52:1.2.eng: Then a person would pick up some water on the tip of a blade of grass.

sn56.52:1.4.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yaṃ vā kusaggena ubbhataṃ, yaṃ vā pokkharaṇiyā udakan”ti?
sn56.52:1.4.eng: Which is more: the water on the tip of the blade of grass, or the water in the lotus pond?”

sn56.52:1.5.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yadidaṃ—pokkharaṇiyā udakaṃ; appamattakaṃ kusaggena udakaṃ ubbhataṃ.
sn56.52:1.5.eng: “Sir, the water in the lotus pond is certainly more. The water on the tip of a blade of grass is tiny.

sn56.52:1.6.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti pokkharaṇiyā udakaṃ upanidhāya kusaggena udakaṃ ubbhatan”ti.
sn56.52:1.6.eng: Compared to the water in the lotus pond, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”

sn56.52:1.7.eng: “In the same way, for a noble disciple …

sn56.52:1.8.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
